an6.48:4.1: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha,
an6.48:4.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
an6.48:4.5: “Master Gotama, they speak of ‘a teaching realizable in this very life’.
an6.48:4.6: In what way is the teaching realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves?”
an6.48:5.1: “Well then, brahmin, I’ll ask you about this in return,
an6.48:5.2: and you can answer as you like.
an6.48:5.3: What do you think, brahmin? When there’s greed in you, do you understand ‘I have greed in me’? And when there’s no greed in you, do you understand ‘I have no greed in me’?”
an6.48:5.6: This is how the teaching is realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
an6.48:6.1: What do you think, brahmin? When there’s hate …
an6.48:6.3: corruption that leads to physical deeds …
an6.48:6.5: When there’s corruption that leads to mental deeds in you, do you understand ‘I have corruption that leads to mental deeds in me’? And when there’s no corruption that leads to mental deeds in you, do you understand ‘I have no corruption that leads to mental deeds in me’?”
an6.48:6.8: this is how the teaching is realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”
an6.48:7.2: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
